prompt: In which novel by Charles Dickens do the characters Susan Nipper and Captain Cuttle appear? Great Expectations.
Which former World Heavyweight boxing champion was nicknamed the 'Cinderella Man'? Mike Tyson.
What was the given Christian name of the fashion designer 'Coco' Chanel? Claire.
Upon which author's best-selling novel was the film 'Psycho' based? Stephen King.
Which actor, (the eighth Doctor Who) played the role just once in a 1996 TV movie? Tom Baker.
Who managed England during the 1982 World Cup? Margaret Thatcher.
Which English king was married to Philippa of Hainault? Henry VIII.
Led for 3 days by veteran Tom Watson, who finally won the 2009 Open Golf Championship? Tiger Woods.
Which opera contains the famous Anvil Chorus in its second act? "Carmen".
The Haworth Art Gallery is located in which Lancashire town? Blackburn.
Which painter, who reputedly sold only one work in his lifetime, had an art dealer brother called Theo? Claude Monet.
Who was the valet of Prince Romiro in Rossini's opera La Cenerentola, also a well-known pantomime character? Pierrot.
In the Sikh religion, what name is given to the Holy Book ontaining the teachings of the gurus? Gita.
Who was the author of the best-selling novel on which the film The Exorcist was based? Stephen King.
Who is the patron saint of dancers and comedians? St Francis of Assisi.
Who starred in the title role of the boxing movie 'The Cinderella Man'? Tom Cruise.
In which Dickens novel do the characters Thomas Traddles and James Steerforth appear? "Great Expectations".
Which city was selected in 2009 as the venue for the 2016 Olympic games? Paris.
Buried in neither Westminster nor Windsor, where is the tomb of Edward II? Canterbury.
Vivaldi's 'Four Seasons' are 4 concertos for which instrument? Harpsichord.
'Eleanor Rigby' and 'Yellow Submarine' first appeared on which Beatles album of 1966? "Rubber Soul".
Who wrote the 2005 bestseller 'The Shadow of the Wind' set in post Spanish Civil War Barcelona? Gabriel García Márquez.
John Adams, 2nd President of the USA, was the delegate to the Continental Congress for which American state? New York.
Which was the last country to join the G8 in 1997 (changing the G7 to G8)? Switzerland.
Who hosted the 2010 ICC World Twenty20 Tournament? Australia.
The 2009 film 'Nowhere Boy' concerns the teenage years of which singer? Elvis Presley.

Which actress is married to Taylor Hackford? Meryl Streep.
Who is the TESCO boss who recently announced his intention to retire? Elon Musk.
In Marvel Comics which God is the alter ego of Donald Blake? Odin.
Who directed the 2004 Oscar winning film 'The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King'? Steven Spielberg.
Rachmaninov's 'Rhapsody on a theme of Paganini' is a work for which solo instrument and orchestra? Violin.
'Yesterday' and 'Ticket to Ride' first appeared on which Beatles album of 1965? "Rubber Soul".
Who wrote the 2006 best seller 'The Book Thief' set in Munich during World War II? JK Rowling.
In Edinburgh what name is given to the streets that link the Castle with Holyrood Palace? Royal Mileways.
Thomas Jefferson, 3rd President of the USA, was the delegate to the Continental Congress for which American state? New York.
In which country will the 2011 Rugby Union World Cup be held? France.
The 2009 film `Inglourious Basterds' is set during which conflict? Vietnam.
Who is the BP Chief Executive recently quizzed by the US Congress? Elon Musk.
Beaune, Nuits St George and Chambertin are wines from which French wine region? Bordeaux.
In a 2010 film Percy Jackson is the son of which Greek God? Zeus.
What is the capital of the French region of Brittany? Nantes.
Which group from Teignmouth has issued albums 'Black Holes & Revelations' and 'The Resistance' Coldplay.
Taraxacum spp is the Latin name for which genus of common wild garden plant? Bellis.
What colour is the artist's colour called vermillion? Blue.
Catherine Morland is a leading character in which novel? Pride and Prejudice.
In which city is Da Vinci's Last Supper on display? Paris.
Which group from Abingdon has issued albums 'Hail to the thief and 'In Rainbows'? The Rolling Stones.
The French Football Ligue 1 team Marseille have which other name in their title? Olympique Lyon.
Who wrote the lyrics and music for A Little Night Music? Andrew Lloyd Webber.
Rumex spp is the Latin name for which genus of common wild garden plant? Dandelion.
Who played the male lead in the 1958 film 'Bell, Book & Candle'? Cary Grant.
In the abbrevation CAFOD - for what does the 'O' stand? Outreach.
In Greek mythology who is the Goddess of Strife? Athena.
Which artist married Saskia van Uylenburg in 1634? Vincent van Gogh.
Grupo Modelo and Femsit are the two major brewing companies in which country? Brazil.
Brad Pitt plays the part of Benjamin Button on film, who wrote the book on which the film is based? F Scott Fitzgerald.
Which company was founded in 1998 by the merger of Grand Metropolitan and Guinness? PepsiCo.
Many cities, including Sofia, Tallinn, St Petersburg, Warsaw, Jerusalem and Belgrade, have cathedrals dedicated to which Russian saint? Alexander Nevsky.
The Oscar winning film 'Aviator' was about which man? Charles Lindbergh.

In which city would you find the following; Aventine, Caelian, Capitoline, Esquiline, Palatine, Quirinal and Viminal? Paris.
What was the name of the seat at King Arthur's Round Table that was reserved for the knight who would one day find the Holy Grail? Excalibur.

Who wrote the line 'The Child is Father of the Man'? Shakespeare.
